unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Brackish Water Salinity
question_text:
In biology class, you learn that the salinity of brackish water (water that is saltier than fresh water, but less salty than ocean water) generally has a mean of $20$ parts per thousand (ppt).
You go to a nature preserve located near the ocean every day at $4$ p.m. for $40$ successive days and measure the salinity of the water at the same spot in the estuary, where fresh water and ocean water mix and mingle.
At the end of the time period, you calculate the mean and standard deviation of the salinity of your $40$ data points and carry out a one-sample t-test about the mean, calculating the test statistic and the p-value.
What assumption concerning hypothesis testing have you violated in carrying out this experiment?
solution:
Choice 'A' is correct; by choosing $40$ successive days, rather than choosing $40$ days at random from (perhaps) an entire year, you run the risk of losing the independence of your observations. If there is a heavy rain on one day, for example, your salinity measures could be affected by that one rainstorm for several days.

Even though this violation is not a deal-breaker for the experiment, it should be mentioned in your experimental report as a possible source of error, and caution should be used in generalizing results.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'B' is incorrect; sample size is plenty large enough.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; since the sample size is large (greater than about $30$), approximate normality of the sampling distribution is assured by the central limit theorem.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; when performing a t-test, one assumption is the population standard deviation is unknown.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; the p-value is not a condition. P-value refers to a probability value obtained after the test statistic is calculated.
